article.description:
Before the Los Angeles Clippers expect to
make it to the playoffs, they first have to get over the .500 mark -- which so far this season has seemed like Mount Everest for coach
Alvin Gentry'
article.headline: Brand leads way with 22 points and 19 rebounds
article.linkText: Clippers closer to getting over .500 after beating Hornets
article.story:
LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Before the Los Angeles Clippers expect to make it to the playoffs, they first have to get over the .500 mark -- which so far this season has seemed like Mount Everest for coach Alvin Gentry's squad. The 89-78 victory Sunday over the Charlotte Hornets put the Clippers at the break-even point for the third time following their opening-night defeat at San Antonio. The other three times, they lost their next game. "We've been there five times already and we didn't get there yet, so I don't want to jinx it," said forward Elton Brand, who had 22 points and 19 rebounds. A victory against Orlando on Monday night in Staples Center would mark the first time the Clippers (10-10) had a winning record this late in a season since March 5, 1993, when they were 29-28 under Larry Brown and went to the playoffs with a 41-41 record. They advanced to the postseason in 1996-97 under Bill Fitch, but never went above .500 after starting out 6-5. "It's up to Coach," Brand said. "It's Coach's job is to keep all these egos in check and keep us in the flow. And he's done a pretty good job of it so far. We can really get better if we can get a run going." Brand made 10 of 12 shots and Jeff McInnis sank four clinching free throws in the final 38 seconds, helping the Clippers beat the Hornets for the first time in eight attempts. Lamar Odom added 14 points and seven assists. David Wesley scored 18 points for the Hornets, and Baron Davis had 16 points and 10 assists. Trailing by 13 points with 5:10 remaining, the Hornets closed to 82-76 with a 21-footer by Wesley and a 3-pointer by Davis with 2:52 left. Odom's short baseline jumper was nullified by his offensive foul, but Davis missed two free throws. The Clippers closed it with a 7-2 spurt. "The difference was our defense," McInnis said. "It's just as hard to play in this league with a lead because you know the other team is going to come back, so the main thing for us was just to keep playing. We started talking a little more and started getting real active." McInnis set up an alley-oop dunk by Corey Maggette and added a layup 32 seconds later as the Clippers extended their 10-point halftime lead to 60-45 with 8:55 left in the third quarter. The Hornets closed to 67-62 on a dunk by Lee Nailon with 9½ minutes to play. Maggette, matched up against Davis and getting a 3-inch height advantage, scored 13 of his 15 points during a 6:37 span of the first quarter to help the Clippers build a 36-21 lead 2½ minutes into the second. Davis, trying to get his teammates involved on offense, had five assists before taking his first shot -- a 3-pointer with 1:21 with left in the opening quarter. He finished 6-for-18 from the field, and 3-for-10 from behind the arc. "I should have played better, but I just couldn't get my motor going," Davis said. "I didn't push myself like I should have and I wasn't aggressive." Game notes
Clippers backup center Sean Rooks, fined $2,500 for missing practice Saturday, was benched by coach Alvin Gentry, who gave Obinna Ekezie a season-high 12 minutes. "They look at it like I'm one of the older guys on the team, so that's really not acceptable to them," said Rooks, who averaged 12 minutes. "But never was I trying to be a disturbance to the team. I mean, people should know me better than that." ... McInnis, who was born in Charlotte and played three seasons at North Carolina, worked out for then-Hornets coach Dave Cowens on draft day 1996. But the team chose Kentucky's Tony Delk with the 16th overall selection, after getting Kobe Bryant three selections earlier. McInnis went on to become the CBA MVP in 2000, and led the NBA last season in assist-to-turnover ratio. ... Davis, who grew up in Los Angeles and played at UCLA, picked up the entire tab for a daylong field trip he organized for about 30 children from South Central Los Angeles. It included the morning shootaround, meeting the Hornets at their hotel, a pizza party, and tickets to the game.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
